On Tue, 2007-12-11 at 17:58 -0800, Paul Jack wrote:
> > Is it possible to explain the rationale for leaving order.xml files
> > behind? I know that we have some investment in the format, and though
> > we can of course move forward it is not clear to me from looking at
> > the sheets.
> 
> There were a number of reasons:
> 
> 1. The XML wasn't well-defined for most modules, so the benefits of  
> XML were mostly lost. Eg, it would be nice to have
> 
> <FetchDNS>
> <accept-non-dns-resolves>false</accept-non-dns-resolves>
> <deciderules/>
> <digest-algorithm>SHA1</digest-algorithm>
> <digest-content>true</digest-content>
> <enabled>true</enabled>
> </FetchDNS>
> 
> ...so that configuration sheets could be validated using standard XML  
> tools. But that would also be a huge departure from the existing  
> order.xml, would require more infrastructure, and would make it more  
> difficult to support third-party modules.

Will it be possible to validate the new structure at all?

> 2. XML's nesting provides a good visual sense of structure for the  
> old order.xml and for the new global sheet, but didn't work so well  
> for override sheets, which typically contain only a few settings.  
> We'd either have to nest many levels of empty tags to get to the  
> actual overrides, or have two different XML formats for the global  
> sheet and override sheets.

I think the sense of structure is a fairly important baby to be throwing
out with the bathwater.  We're actually in NetarchiveSuite moving
towards something that's uses the XML structure more rather than seeing
it as key-value pairs.  

> 3. The one-setting-per-line format plays well with command-line tools  
> such as diff.

That's probably my biggest gripe against XML in general.  There is
xgrep, but it's not nearly at the level of grep in usability.

> 4. The one-setting-per-line format closely resembles the new JMX API  
> for modifying sheets. In particular, code used for JMX transport of  
> settings is re-used to read/write the sheet files.

It's obviously bad to have a different format for modifying sheets, but
couldn't the JMX API use XML instead, passing arbitrary parts of a sheet
XML?

> >> In most cases the values for these new module settings are deduced
> >> automatically by the settings framework, so hopefully you won't have
> >> to worry about them. They are all listed in the Web UI and module
> >> documentation though.
> >
> > Does this mean that there are sensible default values?
> 
> Yes; they default to use the primary. See below.
> 
> > I’m a little bit confused, still. I’m looking at the global.sheet for
> > profile-broad_but_shallow. Some of the items hold values:
> > ‘root:scope:rules:1:max-hops=int, 2’, and some don’t:
> > ‘root:controller:processors:HTTP:accept-headers=list,
> > java.lang.String’. Is this second one an empty string? If so, how are
> > lists defined?
> 
> The second one is not an empty string; it's saying "Create a new list  
> that will only contain String values."

I get nervous twitches every time I see something evolve from fairly
simple to having its own type system (having done that too many times
myself:).  It's a sign that it's getting too complex.  I will admit,
though, that I never quite liked the way the old order.xml files looked,
where the XML tags for most things were the types rather than the
meaning.  I'd find it more readable if the type definitions were outside
the structure, e.g. in a RelaxNG or DSD spec, or at most added as an
attribute.

> 
> > What is the difference between ‘primary, org.archive[...]’ and
> > ‘object, org.archive[...]’?
> 
> Each class of object can have one "primary" object nominated in the  
> global sheet. If  a setting uses the "primary" tag then the object  
> created is registered as the primary.
> 
> Primary objects are automatically selected as the default value for  
> most module settings. For instance, FetchHTTP has a server-cache  
> setting for specifying the ServerCache to use with FetchHTTP. The  
> default value for that setting is to use the "primary" ServerCache.  
> In this way only one ServerCache instance needs to be specified in  
> the sheet, and all the modules that need it just find it.

I like that.  I'll have to remember it for our purposes.

We've talked occasionally about using Spring for settings.  I don't know
yet if Spring is the best, but wouldn't it be more reasonable to follow
some kind of standard for settings files rather than re-inventing the
wheel (much as that is a favorite passtime of programmers:)?

-Lars
